name: Cyproheptadine (Periactin)
summary: A first-generation antihistamine with antiserotonergic properties, used for allergies, appetite stimulation, and serotonin syndrome management.
description: Cyproheptadine is a first-generation antihistamine that also antagonizes serotonin receptors (5-HT2) and muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. It is used for allergic conditions, as an appetite stimulant, and in the treatment of serotonin syndrome. Its sedative properties are significant due to central H1 receptor blockade.

items: Appetite stimulation (e.g., cancer-related cachexia, pediatric underweight)

sections.text: Cyproheptadine blocks histamine H1 receptors, serotonin 5-HT2 receptors, and muscarinic receptors. The antiserotonergic effect makes it useful in serotonin syndrome and appetite stimulation.

adult.allergic-disorders: 4 mg every 8 hours; may increase to 20–32 mg/day in divided doses
adult.appetite-stimulation: 2 mg two to three times daily; may titrate
adult.serotonin-syndrome: 4–8 mg every 1–4 hours until symptoms resolve (acute use)

sections.pediatric: Varies by age; typically 0.25 mg/kg/day in divided doses for allergy indications
sections.geriatric: Use with caution; increased anticholinergic sensitivity

sections.text: Onset within 1–3 hours; duration of action approximately 4–6 hours.

other: Significant sedation may impair performance of hazardous activities
Caution in elderly due to anticholinergic load
Avoid in infants due to paradoxical CNS excitation

items: Weight and BMI during chronic use

sections.pregnancy: Category B; use if benefits outweigh risks
sections.lactation: Avoid; may cause sedation in infant
sections.pediatrics: Avoid in newborns; safe in older children with dosing adjustment
sections.geriatrics: Caution due to increased CNS and anticholinergic sensitivity

sections.text: Generally not required for short-term use; taper may be considered after prolonged high-dose use to avoid rebound symptoms.

items: One of the few serotonin antagonists available for serotonin syndrome treatment
Often used off-label for appetite stimulation in chronic illness and pediatrics
Less commonly used for allergies compared to newer non-sedating antihistamines
